awd_titl_txt: P2C2:  Testing the Timing of the Devils Hole Climate Record
awd_abstract_narration:
This project generally aims to reassess the iconic Devils Hole, Nevada record of climate and hydrology as it is one of the longest continuous records of terrestrial climate change available to researchers. The Devils Hole record has stimulated a quarter of a century of debate with regard to implications about the causes of regional and global climate change and its relationship, or lack thereof, to orbital forcing. The researchers and their collaborators have collected preliminary data that suggests that specific critical portions of this record have anomalous ages, which, if corrected, would change the interpretation of the record dramatically.

The anomalies are associated with samples collected at significant depth below the water table. Those collected near the surface do not appear to have anomalous ages. The research team proposes to test for these anomalies by analyzing cores collected at different depths and obtain a record with an accurate chronology from the shallowest of the cores. They further propose to extend the record back in time to cover the past one million years and increase the resolution of the record substantially. The research team also plans to construct a record of fluctuations in the ground water table at Devils Hole.  Although there are many subtleties to the scientific discussion, the crux of the debate is the degree to which orbital forcing may have played a role in the observed environmental changes.

The Broader Impacts include helping to better understand the factors that control climate and rainfall in a region where water resources are critical, mentoring a postdoctoral research scholar, and the production of a film on cave climate science featuring underwater research at Devils Hole.

por.por_cntn:
This project characterized the history of groundwater at a site, Devils Hole, Nevada, close to Death Valley. Devils Hole is essentially a crack or fissure in the earth, dry near the surface, but filled with groundwater at depth. (See the appended photograph of one of our collaborators climbing down the dry portion of the fissure toward the groundwater.) Deposits of the mineral calcite form from that groundwater and coat the walls of the fissure. The University of Minnesota group along with their collaborators from the University of Innsbruck in Austria collected samples of the calcite deposits in that wall, dated the various layers and analyzed isotope ratios of a number of elements in those layers. From this data, the research team was able to infer the changes in groundwater table elevation and climate in this region from the present extending back 450,000 years or more prehistorically. There are actually two "Devils Holes".  Devils Hole proper and Devils Hole 2. Are work was carried out in Devils Hole 2 as Devils Hole proper is home to an endangered species of pupfish.

  From the standpoint of intellectual merit, our climate records indicate that in the past, the climate in this region was generally wetter than today and that climate shifted dramatically many times in the last half million years between wetter and drier conditions. These shifts are related to natural changes in the carbon dioxide concentration of the atmosphere, to the ice age cycles, to changes in the earth's season's related to changes in the geometry of the earth's orbit and axis of rotation, and to abrupt changes in earth's climate observed elsewhere around the world.

  The broader impacts of our work are three-fold. First, the climate records establish a natural climate backdrop for us to view future changes in climate, in a region where future water availability is important. Second, as part of training the next generation of climate scientists this project has fostered the training of multiple scientists early in their professional careers. Third, the group has consulted with cinematographer, Jonathan Byrd, and actually acted in Jonathan Byrd's IMAX film Ancient Caves, which features spectacular full dome shots of Devils Hole 2 and other caves around the world. The world premiere was in March 2020 at the Science Museum of Minnesota and the film is currently showing at a number of sites around the United States.
